update.description:
To test the PR:

open ` http/client/sdfViewerExample.html `

1. for the materials file, you can either use thee one that I made from [here](https://gist.github.com/MohmadAyman/4c2f904d279d63175acd361847ba03da)

Or you can generate the `materials json` file yourself using the `material-parser` npm package running those commands:

     1. `npm init` 

     2. `npm install material-parser`

     3. `node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>`

2. select a folder containing a model <all it's assets included Textures, meshes ...etc>

3. View the model.
 
The materials for the object files are not handled yet, I'm working on a PR in THREE.js that would allow us to handle them.

***** set up grunt and cmake

* simple demo working

* materials added as an argument,  grunt files order fixed

* added a separate file for sdfviewer_gui, removed unused code from example html

* use only single quotes in karma and add angular mocks

* minimal gui used
update.title: Gzweb as sdfparser
update.reason: will break it into small PRs

content.raw:
cool, I have it mostly working! The double pendulum and gas station models work great.

A couple of issues:

* When uploading models, I am able to change the path of the model directory but the list of files do not refresh.

* The cordless drill model is black. The browser seems to be looking for the texture in an undefined directory: `file:///media/ian/tmp/depot/gzweb/http/client/undefined../materials/textures/cordless_drill.png`
content.html:
cool, I have it mostly working! The double pendulum and gas station models work great.

A couple of issues:

  • When uploading models, I am able to change the path of the model directory but the list of files do not refresh.

  • The cordless drill model is black. The browser seems to be looking for the texture in an undefined directory: file:///media/ian/tmp/depot/gzweb/http/client/undefined../materials/textures/cordless_drill.png

content.raw: For step 3 of the instruction, I had to do `node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>`
content.html: For step 3 of the instruction, I had to do node node_modules/material-parser/index.js <path to gzweb assets>

content.raw:
I see compile warning when doing `npm install material-parser`:

~~~
../GZNode.cc: In static member function ‘static void gzweb::GZNode::LoadMaterialScripts(const v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>&)’:
../GZNode.cc:72:11: warning: unused variable ‘obj’ [-Wunused-variable]
   GZNode* obj = ObjectWrap::Unwrap<GZNode>(args.This());
~~~

that's probably in the `material-parser` package
content.html:
I see compile warning when doing npm install material-parser:

../GZNode.cc: In static member function ‘static void gzweb::GZNode::LoadMaterialScripts(const v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>&)’:
../GZNode.cc:72:11: warning: unused variable ‘obj’ [-Wunused-variable]
   GZNode* obj = ObjectWrap::Unwrap<GZNode>(args.This());

that's probably in the material-parser package

content.raw: No not really, I just didn't notice them xD
content.html: No not really, I just didn't notice them xD

content.raw: Are the comments necessary?
content.html: Are the comments necessary?

content.raw: Do you mind moving this change to a new pull request, with a test so we're sure the function works with and without files? It would also be nice to add more documentation, for example, what's the relation between `files` and `uri` now, is it either one or the other?
content.html: Do you mind moving this change to a new pull request, with a test so we're sure the function works with and without files? It would also be nice to add more documentation, for example, what's the relation between files and uri now, is it either one or the other?

content.raw: Is this needed for the SDF viewer? I see a lot of functions in this file which could be removed in the future. It would be interesting to audit the whole file later and trim it down to what's absolutely necessary. For now, we can keep it long.
content.html: Is this needed for the SDF viewer? I see a lot of functions in this file which could be removed in the future. It would be interesting to audit the whole file later and trim it down to what's absolutely necessary. For now, we can keep it long.

content.raw: Yup, now I can see the pendulum with no errors, thanks!
content.html: Yup, now I can see the pendulum with no errors, thanks!

To test the PR:

open ` http/client/sdfViewerExample.html `

1. for the materials file, you can either use thee one that I made from [here](https://gist.github.com/MohmadAyman/4c2f904d279d63175acd361847ba03da)

Or you can generate the `materials json` file yourself using the `material-parser` npm package running those commands:

     1. `npm init` 

     2. `npm install material-parser`

     3. `node index.js <the path to the materials -in my case that was `/gzweb/http/client/assets` >

2. select a folder containing a model <all it's assets included Textures, meshes ...etc>

3. View the model.
 
The materials for the object files are not handled yet, I'm working on a PR in THREE.js that would allow us to handle them.

***** set up grunt and cmake

* simple demo working

* materials added as an argument,  grunt files order fixed

* added a separate file for sdfviewer_gui, removed unused code from example html

* use only single quotes in karma and add angular mocks

* minimal gui used

content.raw:
Now it's working better for me, not sure if it was a local cache of mine or something you changed, but now I can successfully open models like  `cordless_drill` and `fast_food`! They show without a texture, which is expected. 

However, models like `double_pendulum_with_base` and `demo_joint_types`, which are composed of simple shapes and no mesh, are not coming up. I just see an empty world with a grid.

content.raw:
Yes almost all of the code is from the gzbridge, 

The motivation to have it in a separate was that we want to make the ```sdfviewer``` headless and reusable, so, e.g. I'm a user who want to try my model on the ```sdfviewer``` , since we don't parse materials right now in the ```sdfviewer``` -to make it headless-, I thought a separate package for users to parse their materials would be a suitable choice. 

This might not be the best idea, but it did the job and was fine for me.

About the file that is not being parsed, I believe if the package couldn't parse it ```gzweb``` is not supposed to be able to too, which file was it?
content.html:
Yes almost all of the code is from the gzbridge,

The motivation to have it in a separate was that we want to make the sdfviewer headless and reusable, so, e.g. I'm a user who want to try my model on the sdfviewer , since we don't parse materials right now in the sdfviewer -to make it headless-, I thought a separate package for users to parse their materials would be a suitable choice.

This might not be the best idea, but it did the job and was fine for me.

About the file that is not being parsed, I believe if the package couldn't parse it gzweb is not supposed to be able to too, which file was it?

content.raw:
I was just trying out the material parser, and I wasn't able to parse a file. 

I was wondering what is the motivation for having it in a separate package, do we think this may be useful for other applications? The code seems to be quite gzweb-specific. Maybe we can just keep that within GzWeb.
content.html:
I was just trying out the material parser, and I wasn't able to parse a file.

I was wondering what is the motivation for having it in a separate package, do we think this may be useful for other applications? The code seems to be quite gzweb-specific. Maybe we can just keep that within GzWeb.

content.raw: Okay thanks, will add this to the description (y).
content.html: Okay thanks, will add this to the description (y).

content.raw: you may want to mention in your package description that it works with ogre versions < 1.10 as ogre 2.0 uses a new and different material system
content.html: you may want to mention in your package description that it works with ogre versions < 1.10 as ogre 2.0 uses a new and different material system
